{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3344758,"name":"","username":"RoyalKnight","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/ce7236/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-27T00:11:43.150Z","cooked":"

Hello!

I am the lead programmer for team 5842! Our season has come to an end which means it is time to learn something new! Our team has never successfully used vision for anything and I hope to change that during this offseason. I was wondering if anyone had any tips for me to start? I was hoping to start with basic PoseEstimation so that PathPlanner is as accurate as possible. Any first steps? Any help is truly appreciated!! We have a limelight, i would rather not go too complicated with a different processor on my first go but if thats the best way then so be it. Thanks so much for the help in advance!

Get apriltags running on the limelight and feed the pose into your odometry filter

Limelight documentation is a good place to start; I would recommend reading the entire apriltags section

docs.limelightvision.io

Robot Localization with MegaTag | Limelight Documentation

If your Limelight's robot-space pose has been configured in the web ui, and a field map has been uploaded via the web ui, then the robot's location in field space

Thanks a lot! Will do!

This is our code…GitHub - Royal-Robotics-5842/Royal_Robotics_FRC_2024

As you can see it is very basic so I was wondering if you have any code that I could look at to see where all the functions and things are implemented? That usually helps me understand what I am missing! Thanks for the help!

I don’t have any code that feeds the limelight pose into a swerve odometry object, but:

You can get the pose returned by the limelight using:

double[] pos =
        NetworkTableInstance.getDefault()
            .getTable("limelight")
            .getEntry("botpose")
            .getDoubleArray(new double[6]);

pos will be in the form:
[x, y, z, something, something, yaw, latency]

You then need to swap out your swerveDriveOdometry for a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Pose Estimators

WPILib includes pose estimators for differential, swerve and mecanum drivetrains. These estimators are designed to be drop-in replacements for the existing odometry classes that also support fusing...
